item.description:
Starzone is a print-and-play game for 2 players set in outer space. Each player battles with a fleet of spacecraft by flicking coins into the Starzone target. The Starzone target is made up of different zones, and asteroids which litter space. Which zone you hit determines which action you take: you can repair your spacecraft, activate your shields, add or destroy asteroids on the target, or damage your opponent's spacecraft. A special Zone Shift zone on the target allows you to change which actions can be activated by hitting each zone, adding a tactical element to the game. Your spacecraft has different sectors, and the health of each sector is given by hit points. When one sector is destroyed then your spacecraft is destroyed. The first player to destroy three of their enemy's fleet wins the game.

Starzone is a fun and furious game of dexterity and strategy. Outwit your opponent using asteroids and zone-shifts. Find your enemy's weak spot and flick it into outer space!

Players take the role of MATRIX RUNNERS (2-4 players) characters with unique advantages, disadvantages & specialty RIGS which they use to hack into the Cybernet.

Players take missions, complete them, hack into systems, enter battle arenas, invest in upgrading, or purchasing programs, and taking on more & more difficult challenges, all the while dodging traces, system guardians, & other players who may be trying to collect a bounty on them.

It's always risky engaging with other players in the net.
this provides them with the ability to trade or sell each other programs, or reveal information (for a price). But you never know if the mission they're on is to catch you & destroy you.
if you get caught, you can get fined, you programs can become corrupted, or you could face a serious virus is infecting your rig, or worse, eliminated!
It is a game of covert operations, espionage, and power. The more you earn the better the hardware & software you can buy, and become better equipped to move on to bigger and better things, but you never know who could be after you & who can be your ally.

The Year is 2055
The world is run by 3 major corporations,

GLOBE-E-TRON, E-Vision, and NOVA CORPS.
Sovereignty of Countries, and Governments have become obsolete.
The once known Internet has evolved into a vast Virtual Cybernet, where millions of people live out their
fantasy in virtual entertainment. The WORLD has become solely dependent on this Cybernet.
Corporations that virtually govern the world have reputation to uphold, 
so they hire MATRIX RUNNERS to do their dirty work.
Sometimes these RUNS, include:
Hacking Important information on a new product, 
Retrieve info on corporate activity, 
Eliminate the competition by destroying their system. 
Other jobs include hunting down other hackers as well,
Because of this vast underground employment market, a secret organization has developed an agency to facilitate 
these jobs, keeping both the employer, and runner safe and anonymous.
This AGENCY also provides illegal programs to registered RUNNERS & provides them with jobs.
They are simply referred to as THE AGENCY.
It is a dangerous world of Intrigue, Deception, Skill, and Subterfuge. Noone is truly safe, and anyone can be traced and Eliminated. Tread carefully, young Runner...

item.description: Party game. Twelve pictures of composite animals are placed around the room. During the party, guests look at the pictures and write down the animals that make up each image. The one who gets the most right answers, wins.

Party game, with 16 cards, all with at least one thing wrong in the picture.

Cards are distributed around the room and guests are encouraged to look at the cards during the party, and to note down any faults they can see in the image. The one who gets the most right, wins.

item.description:
All participants answer the same yes/no question about personal opinions or things done in the past at the same time by inserting a note in to the answer box. Then everyone makes a secret quess about the total number of "Yes"-answers. Those who get the correct answer get one point. The game ends when someone has 10 points.

Questions are designed for adults and might concer even outlaw things.

From the rulebook Designer's note:

"The original version of SC3600 was developed and published by Mariner Games back in 1997. The original launch was accompanied by a small range of miniatures developed by Brigade Models. However the original designers, Patrick Doyle, Mike Tastsides and Doug Glover were serving members of the US armed forces and as such had more pressing demands on their time than playing games, so development of the rules understandably stalled.
[...] We've avoided unnecessary changes to the core rules, being content to tinker around the edges with minor changes to the design system and the inclusion of a hex-less movement system. Our main goal has been to streamline the rules a little without drastically altering the flavour. Probably the one major change has been to do away with the 12-point movement system that allowed movement along hex edges - we abandoned this in our own games very early on. We've also removed the distinction between the Basic and Advanced versions of the game in favour of a single unified set of rules."

The game uses miniatures of starfighters, it is played on a hex map but a set of rules to use hexless maps is also included. The main dice roll used is the 2d6 roll, this is modified by another kinf of dice (ranging from a d4 to a d12) based on the pilot skill. These dice rolls are used to resolve fights and control rolls when your fighter is going spinning around due to damages or wrong manouvers. The damage system is very interesting, being it not the "classic" set of boxes that have to be crossed out but a system that takes in account a series of debilitating damages that during the game, imposing each a number of malus and penalties, can render your fighter inoperative or totally destroyed. Statistics for the official fighter models are in the end of the book.

These are introductory free rules, Brigade Models is going to publish in a near future more complete rules (this time you are going to buy them) that will also include campaign games rules, pilots' skill progression and others more convoluted situations not presented here.

item.description: Japanese card game that has numbered sickness cards and numbered medicine cards. When you get sickness and medicine card with same number, you can throw them away. First player to get rid of all hand cards wins the game.

item.description:
ABOUT THE GAME

Outside the Box™ was designed to be unique in many ways. First of all, the box top or cover actually becomes the game board (we don’t think anyone has ever done this before), hence the name Outside the Box. Secondly, it is a team game (there are very few team games out there) where everyone is actively involved throughout the game. This makes it a great party game, but also gives every single player a chance to be a hero by helping his or her team win. Most importantly, Outside the Box is all skill. There are no dice. Teams can only advance by getting the answers right. It’s very fast. It’s very fun and it’s very, very addictive.

GAME PLAY

Outside the Box™ consists of four types of rounds: Volley Box, Team Play, To Each His Own, and Speed Round. In most rounds, answers are given, in order, A through Z. Teams begin on the Start square with a Volley Box round. The team that wins the Volley Box moves onto the board to the first Team Play space, receives 3 PassCards, and will play the first Team Play round. As your teams progress through the game, you advance through 3 phases, and the 377 categories become more challenging. To win the game, you leave Phase 3, flip over the Start square (which reveals the Winner's Box), and attempt your Final Challenge.

FOUR ROUNDS OF PLAY

With four different rounds and hundreds of categories, it's like playing four games in one...so it's never the same, as it changes each time you play. Here are some examples:

Team Play - You have been chosen as the Captain of your team for this round. The category is: "Musical Groups and Rock Bands." The timer is set for 2 minutes, and the pressure is on! You must go, in order, A through Z, and name a group or band that begins with each letter of the alphabet. Your team may help you, but only by giving you "outside the box" clues. Did you just say, "That's easy?" Ready, set, go!

Volley Box - In this round, teams battle back and forth through the alphabet in a verbal hot potato! The category is: "Things you give, share, or offer to others." The timer is placed away from view and is set for 1 minute. Again, going in order, A through Z, the first team could shout, "Alimony!" The other team might respond with, "Benefit of the doubt!" The first team says, "Condolences!" (or "Cup of sugar!" or "Custody!" or "CPR!" or "Coat!") The team that is stuck when the timer beeps loses the round. Just how far "outside the box" will you go to help your team win?

To Each His Own - The category is picked and 4 letters are randomly chosen from the alphabet. Both teams are given 2 minutes to secretly write down a response for each letter. Try not to match each other. If you're really good, you may just get the chance to "stump the Master!"

Speed Round - You are the "Actor." You have picked a Speed Round card and the timer is set. You must go in order through the alphabet and get your team to say exactly what is on that card. Go ahead, jump around, sing, use props -- but you better not say any part of the words on the card, or "it sounds like" or "rhymes with.." The timer is going... what are you waiting for?

CONTENTS

Included are 377 category cards with thousands of possible answers (which makes the game different each time you play). The Master List is a three year compilation of well over 15,000 possible responses in which you could get the chance to stump the “Master” by coming up with your own “outside the box” answers. Also included is an audio CD featuring the inventor of the game, Rick Sugarman, explaining the rules. There are also live unscripted role playing examples, as well as helpful hints. In addition, the game comes complete with easy-to-follow, learn-as-you-play instructions and quick reference cards, an electronic digital programmable timer (battery included), team game pawns, scoring chips, letter cards, and PassCards.

BraveRats, first released as R, is a simple and short simultaneous action selection game for two that's played with cards. Both players have a hand of eight cards, numbered 0 to 7, with each card having a special power. Both players choose a card, then reveal them simultaneously. The highest card wins the round, and players play until someone has won four rounds. The cards' special powers greatly influence the game.

item.description:
User summary:
A simple dice game starring characters from Toho fame. Players take turns rolling the character dice. Any character but the Fairy Queen may be kept and the others rerolled. A three-dice, full house, four-dice or five-dice (of anything but the Fairy Queen) is worth points. Also, the quartet of all four idiots (Cirno, Lumia, Wriggle and Mystia) plus Fairy Queen also gives points.

The first player to a set number of points wins.

The games comes with 5 dice, a score sheet and a handkerchief to roll the dice on.

For 1 to 5 players, aged older than the March Fairy.

User summary:

A Dominion-esque Japanese small press deck building game based on web-based role playing game "False Island". All players start with a small set of cards containing money and some victory points, and may each turn play cards from their hand to purchase better cards. The cards available for purchase vary each turn, as they are drawn and displayed 4 at a time from a shuffled pile of various cards. Money cards and victory point cards can always be drawn.

User summary:

A Japanese amateur card game, featuring characters of Shrine Maiden fame. The game simulates a race, and the deck of cards consists of character cards with numbers 1–6 and special powers of varying sorts. Each player starts with a hand of 5 cards, and each turn draws a card and may choose to play a card on theiur own "route" (representing that they are advancing), onto another player (representing an enemy), or generally using a card's special power. The player may also choose to score one of their route cards. Defeating enemies that other players have played on you may also generate points.

Once at 5 route cards, the stage is cleared and the player receives one of the route cards as stage clear bonus, and once a player has cleared 4 stages, the game ends at which point the player with the highest amount of points wins.

User summary:

A "Great Dalmuti" type card game featuring characters of Shrine Maiden fame. The card deck consists of cards numbered 1–15 and a special power. Each player gets 7 cards. The first player may play 1 or more cards (several cards of the same number or a straight), and the players who follow must play as many or more cards as the previous player and the total value must also be higher. Each time one or several card(s) are played, the effect of one of the played card is executed. Players who cannot play must pass. Once everyone around the table has passed, the played cards are discarded and the current players begins anew with playing one or several cards.

The first player to get rid of his hand wins the round. The game is played for several rounds, with the winner of the previous round getting an advantage for the next round.

item.description:
User summary:

A home-made "Hero Quest" type game. The game is played on a square-gridded board representing a dungeon. One player takes the role of the Dungeon Master, the other players are heroes trying to defeat and clear each scenarion.

The game contains a game board, rulebook with 10 scenarios and cut-out markers for all enemies and items.

Game description from the publisher:

It's the distant future, and mankind has taken a galactic leap forward through space, time, and technology. Life as we know it struggles to endure on the Abaddon. Once the home of a mysterious, non-human civilization, the planet is now a desolate wasteland bearing one immensely precious resource: Feronium power crystals. The unimaginable energy contained within the crystals is coveted by two groups of humans: the Satellite City-States and the Commonwealth Alliance. Using Links – giant bio-mech suits made from modified military vehicles and alien technology – the warring factions fight a weary battle for territorial control of the Abaddon.

At your disposal in Abaddon is a 28" x 19" battlefield game board with 32 highly-detailed mech figurines, 18 free-standing landscape terrain features, over 100 game-changing Wild Fire and Weapon System cards, dozens of tokens, battle dice and a Battle Manual containing over 15 mission scenarios. Choose your allegiance and lead your army in non-stop excitement as you forge through unforgiving terrain, fight to overcome random and bizarre technological glitches, and battle your enemies in never-ending war.

Abaddon is a furious, two-to-four-player game of futuristic combat. Each scenario is laid out on the customizable battlefield game board with each side using a varying number of units. The game is played in turns during which a player rolls his Activation Dice, allowing him to "activate" certain units and move them. These mechanical units – Links – are powered by Feronium power crystals, and as they take damage these crystals are depleted. A unit that runs out of crystals is unable to continue functioning and is considered destroyed.

Combat is card- and dice-based. The attacker lays out his Weapon System cards, targeting defending enemy units. Once the attacker has laid out all of his planned attacks, the defender may defend with his own Weapon System cards. These cards can modify the dice rolls that are used to determine the results of the combat. Additionally, due to the experimental nature of the Links and the mysterious happenings in the Abaddon region, things can, and often will, go wrong. These malfunctions and odd happenings are represented by Wild Fire cards, the drawing of which can result in anything from possible shutdowns to anti-gravity surges.

Victory is determined based on stipulations presented by the chosen mission scenarios. Typically, victory is achieved by damaging and destroying your opponent's units by way of their power crystals. Each destroyed enemy crystal is worth one victory point, which players must collect in order to win.

item.description:
ZOMBIE APOCALYPSE is a Card Game of survival horror where 2-4 players each control groups of Humans and Zombies in an effort to survive the Zombie Apocalypse. Humans are greatly outnumbered, but are able to use Weapons and Refuges for protection. Cards like Zombie Horde and Reinforcements can quickly change momentum, but be especially careful of the Zombie Apocalypse card which always keeps the Humans' chances of survival slim at best. In the end, the player with the most Humans and Zombies left standing (or shamblimg), as well as in their Kill Pile, is declared the winner.
 With various "Theme Decks" available (which pushes the number of unique cards in the game to nearly 300), there is a simplified Deck Building system in place that allows some customization while keeping deck strengths equal. Deck Building is more about "atmosphere" than anything else in ZA.
 Finally, all cards use stunning photography! Each card bleeds creepiness and dark humor unlike anything ever seen in a Zombie card game.

item.description:
This game was designed to teach children constructive and effective ways to resolve their anger. The cards allow them the opportunity to choose alternatives that can turn anger-inciting situations into more positive encounters. Through repetitive game play, they will learn how to use the new solutions in real life to avoid negative reactions. The object of the the game is for players to resolve as many anger-inciting situations as they can within a 20-30-minute periods. Players get chips for resolving anger situations, and the player with the most chips wins the game.

Contents:
20 People cards
40 Situation cards
40 Solution cards (four sets of 10)
100 Chips
Instructions

The Earth is probably doomed, and rumors and speculation run rampant. Newspaper headlines from across the globe stir the populace to desperation:

"MELTING POLAR ICE CAPS" "RISING SEA LEVELS" "POLLUTION!" "OVERPOPULATION!" "NUCLEAR WINTER?" "RAVENOUS BLACK STAR GOATS?" "WILL METEORS STRIKE YOUR CHILDREN?" "DISASTER LOOMS!"

The race to escape Earth has begun! With the world's nations in decline, powerful corporations now stand as humanity's last hope. Take the reins of one such corporation, as CEO, and venture out into space. With your mission in hand; build ships, collect resources, research technologies, survive the dangers of space exploration, and, while ticket sales hold steady, preserve the human race. Remember to stay a step ahead of competing corporations, which can use slick marketing campaigns and 10 cent tchotchkes to buy the loyalty of the people you just saved from certain doom!

In Disaster Looms!, players are rewarded points for sticking to the mission and building colonies, and saving colonists. As you are a CEO you are also rewarded points for filling the Corporate treasury, and building the company's value proposition by retaining rights to the best technologies. Gameplay is fast, and exciting. Events, and the vast variety of hazards that space has to offer will keep you on your toes, and your underlings busy on the paperwork for decades to come!

The game is played in five phases: Research, Fleet, Management, Revenue, and finally First Player Turn Auction. All players will complete each phase, in turn order, before proceeding to the next phase. This helps to keep the game moving, and keeps players engaged. In Research phase players can pay to research, or choose to license another players tech. In the Fleet phase players get one action with each ship they own. The Management phase is when players build new ships, special tech items, and sell technology to the public domain. The Revenue phase is when players collect their hard earned resources, including a small stipend from their home office on Earth. And finally, the turn auction phase is a bidding war for who goes first. Not that important at the start of the game, but monumental for the end.

item.description:
Note from designer: This was planned but never got published.

A new murder at East Highway. There is no time to lose before the hints are lost. Due to new methods there are new ways to discover the murder for the investigators. Find root of hairs, fingerprints and autopsy dead bodies.

The players are cadets of Scotland Yard, who create stories about one of the prime suspects in a murder case using "evidence" cards. On the back of the card, the players decode a question with a red foil. If you answer these questions correctly, it will lead you to the murderers.

Crime & Mystery: Modern Investigation is a deductive game for 3 to 6 investigators. It is a part of the Crime & Mystery family and is based on the mechanism of Crime & Mystery: Bakerstreet Files. It puts the investigation into the setting of CSI in the USA.


Schon wieder ein Mord am East Highway. Wie immer gilt es, keine Zeit zu verlieren. Die Spuren muÌˆssen gesichert werden, bevor sie verloren gehen. Dank den neuesten Methoden der Wissenschaft, hat sich das Gesicht der Ermittlungen in solchen FaÌˆllen geaÌˆndert. Haarwurzeln, FingerabdruÌˆcke, Blutproben, Insektenlarven und praÌˆzise Autopsien ermoÌˆglichen eine ganz neue Form der VerbrechensbekaÌˆmpfung. Und auch eine neue Art von Ermittlern.

Crime & Mystery: Modern Investigation ist ein deduktives Spiel fuÌˆr 3-6 Ermittler, das auf dem Spielmechanismus von Crime & Mystery: Bakerstreet Files beruht und die Ermittlungen in das Setting der Crime Scene Investigation der USA fuÌˆhrt.

Objective: be the first collecting 5 knowledge cards out of 5 different (coloured) theme areas:
versions & technology
milestones
sports
design
innovation & environment

 - moving by turn - 
During player's turn die is rolled, may move into any direction, but not vice versa; occupied spaces may be crossed.
Appropriate card is drawn, pick up question - if the answer is correct keep the card.
 Board, 5 x 50 cards with more than 1000 questions
24 action cards, 6 meeples, 1 die, rule sheet

Schlock Mercenary: Capital Offensive is a multi-player tactical shooter, played on a grid-based modular map, set in the popular Schlock Mercenary epic science fiction webcomic created by Howard Tayler. Players take on the roles of Tagon's Toughs and a variety of other characters while working to achieve scenario-specific goals.

Schlock Mercenary: Capital Offensive includes roughly one hundred pieces of original artwork, including top down floor tiles, plasma cannons, scanners, turrets, Teraport cages, and more. The game includes several scenarios, with more scheduled for release in future years.

Featured characters from the comic are Tagon, Elf, Schlock, Ennesby, Legs, Thurl, Kevin, Shodan, Elizabeth, Petey, and Partnership Collective Drones.

item.description:
"I've created a monster!"

The objetive of this game is to be the first one to complete a "Monster man" with all his body parts (head, arms, torso and legs). The mechanic it's a simple "retrieve a card from the deck, discard the one you don't need" (although there are several specific cards wich triggers special events) until you complete your monster. To achieve this, the player can use different parts, as long as the creature is complete.

Game themed on Disney Italia's W.I.T.C.H. comic.

item.description:
Tinker-bell game.

Players try to get rid of all of their glass balls. First a player draws a card with a number or a simple calculation like 3-1, and then the player throws a die which shows either - or +. If the die shows +, player puts as many glass balls as was written on the card on the flower in the middle of the board. If the die shows - player takes glass balls from the flower. When the flower falls down, player has to take all the fallen glass balls.

Objective: 2 players or two teams are attempting 
A capture Big Boy or (Dick Tracy)
B get into head quarter (Big Boy)
- moving by turn -
player rolls the die & moves; if you meet an opponent you are going to fight (by die); loser is placed into the hospital, winner moves on.
Story is based upon the movie published 1990, where the cop Dick Tracy is trying to capture his arch enemy Big Boy Caprice

The aim of the game is to collect all 5 of your rescue cards by remembering where they are.

There is a big spinner in the middle of the table and players spin Fireman Sam as hard as they can!
If he stops by your marker, listen carefully to what is said.

Depending what Fireman Sam said player draws one or two rescue cards and if it is his hero on that card he takes it on his hand or if it's not puts it back in the circle around spinner.
But sometimes Norman is in trouble! Now player have to give back randomly one of his rescue card.

The first player to collect all their 5 hero cards wins!

Objective: Using the detailed street map of Mainz & Wiesbaden each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the centre as possible.

With the help of dice and counters, each players chooses where to place, turn or remove company tiles.
Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four 'places worth seeing' are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Contents: 80 cards, 8 counters, 3 dice, rules and city information.

The year is 2450. The players, who represent different universities from around the world, will travel five hundred years back in time to the 20th century, where they will plan and deliver one of the great advances in that century. Each of these advances has some requirements on personnel, materials and funding. During the game players take turns to play cards on the table (while keeping some cards to achieve their secret agendas); the cards played on the table help in meeting the requirements, but as more cards are on the table there are more probabilities of problems arising in the common research (at the end of each turn a number of dice is rolled depending on the number of cards on the table, and the result of the dice roll sometimes forces to remove some cards). After 10 turns, players win if they have reached the requirements, and one of the players will be the top winner if he/she has also reached his/her secret agenda. If the players have not reached the requirements, they collectively lose.

Inventum is a game of collaboration that highlights the role universites play in transferring knowledge to the community at large and hereby contributing to our economic and social well-being.

The game is published with the support of the University of Barcelona and the Fundació Bosch i Gimpera, from an original proposal by Marga Becerra and Mariona Ferrer.

Objective: Using the detailed street map of Duisburg each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the centre as possible.

With the help of dice and counters, each players chooses where to place, turn or remove company tiles.
Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four 'places worth seeing' are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Contents: 80 cards, 8 counters, 3 dice, rules and city information.

Objective: Using the detailed street map of Frankfurt each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the centre as possible.

With the help of dice and counters, each players chooses where to place, turn or remove company tiles.
Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four 'places worth seeing' are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Three old men and a small child all sit around a small duck pond, tossing breadcrumbs into the water. With each ripple from a crumb, ducks race toward the new treat. (They never actually get the snack, due to the wily fish just below the surface, but it doesn't dissuade them from trying!) Passersby watch the scene for a moment, then smile, charmed by these four people idling away their time. Little do they realize that these crafty individuals actually have a standing wager: Each has chosen a color of duck in the pond as his own, and whoever can gather his ducks into a group first gets to choose the adventure for the day!

Feed the ducks is a board game for two to four players. Each game lasts about 20 minutes. Players drop breadcrumbs into the pond, in order to attract the ducks. There are ducks in 4 colors. The first player to coerce all the ducks of his color into a single group wins.

The basic set includes components for a 2-player game. In order to play 3- or 4-player games you need the additional ducks and counters (red and blue).

MATERIAL

This is what you need in order to play Feed the ducks:

- A board depicting a pond with 61 hexagonal spaces.

- 12 white ducks, 12 black ducks (plus 8 red ducks and 6 blue ducks optionally).

- A breadcrumb (not included)

- One white counter, one black counter (plus one red counter and one blue counter optionally).

- A carrying case.

item.description:
Point Blank is a brand new squad level skirmish system for 1:1 modern tactical firearm combat. Players are in charge of a squad or several fire teams and control the individual actions of their soldiers, weapon teams, vehicles or support weapons. The rules are focused on the tactical concepts of fire and maneuver, command and control, and morale as well as training and experience. Any period of modern firearms combat can be simulated, from The Great War all the way to today and beyond.

The Point Blank book contains everything you need to run games with infantry, artillery, and vehicles as well as rules for spotting and hiding, as well as night, weather, smoke, and fog. There are three major periods represented for the army lists in the book: WWII (which includes Germany, U.S., Soviet, British, French, and Polish. Vietnam (which includes U.S., ARVN, Australian, NVA, and VC. As well as modern forces for the Global War on Terror or any other modern hot spot (which includes U.S., British, Mujahideen, and Insurgent). Rounding out the book are three scenarios, each one concentrating on one of the periods covered in the book and focusing on a tactical concept. The missions include Combat Patrol, Ambush, and a VIP Snatch. There is lots more besides in this 94 page rulebook to keep players busy and gaming.

Pairs draw cards which have body parts, for example fingers-fingers or thumb-forehead and the pair has to place card between those body parts. Pairs continue to add more cards, when first card falls the game is over for that pair.

Objective: "Après-Ski" implicates party ==>
20 different party games, splitted into

Games using dice: "Herr Pes", "Mäxchen", "Schweinejagd", "Spaß im Glas", "Eisbär", "Crash Down".

Games using cards: "Mogeln", "Kartenblasen", "Kartenklopfen", "Mau Wau", "Pech gehabt", "Nummer 7", "Paare finden".

Games for groups: "Kommando Pümperle", "Rippl Dippl", "Handgemenge", "Peter und Paul".

Communication games: "Obacht"(caution ==> pantomime and describing - mini 'Activity'), "Gefragt" (questioned ==> associate words) a und "Wörter finden" (building words - 'Pass the Bomb' without bomb), equipped with 55 question cards. 
If someone 'fails' during a game he/she is collecting a 'Gaudipunkt' (= penalty), which immidiately leads to prior defined consequences (addult game)

more or less all of these small games had been already published by Piatnik years/decades ago - they are muddled along
into a mini edition

Objective: be the first to pass the finish line
 - acting by turn -

using a die, picking up cards and finding the correct answer let your meeple move along 
2 different editions: 1994 and 1997
content: 1000 questions out of Old and New Testament

This game is built the biggest guild by the winner. The players take any shops and building, and the guild is more spread with special ranked people.

The order is decided by the auction as one time. The turn player take the building from one of kingdoms, and place in own player's area, or take any materials from own building, additionally
can take the help from one of kingdom.
Each player has the player's area in the front. The building cards are placed as like a pyramid to upper side.
Then the special ranked people also are placed as like a pyramid to downside.
Any cards are pointed.

However, sometimes the war is occurred.
Each player uses the worriers in the player's area. When lose, the player will lose a building. In the worst case, the special ranked people will leave.

The beautiful kingdom cards are drawn the icon in both sides. The helps change at each round. And in one game, some of the kingdom cards are used; players can play the different kingdoms at every time.
Many building cards are not only produced any materials, also changed any materials to other materials and products. The other building can keep more materials and worriers, and so on.
The materials are many cubes. They are used in order to build the great building and the special ranked people.

This is the card game, but the volume is same with the middle sides of board game.

“Asalto al poder” (Assault on power) is a strategy game that takes place in the world of business and influence peddling. The player will have the opportunity to get rich doing business both legal and illegal (scams), obtaining grants, creating enemies, going to trials ...

The game begins with an election to determine who initially hold the different powers (central, regional and local). With these premises, each player must manage the money they have to achieve the objective that will be assigned at the beginning of the game.

From the publisher:
New children game from Tactic, where each player takes a roll of a small monster, who is looking to grow and get scarier.
Each player has a small board in front of them where they have 5x3 table of circles which needs to be filled with food.
Game has 12 different foods (drinks, hamburgers etc) Each row must have 5 different foods, but at least 1 drink.
When you are able to complete a row, you will receive a small special ability which helps you to get bigger faster and easier.
Monsters go around the board and collect food with different tasks (dice oriented tasks) and watch put from each other.
There are 4 monsters together and each one has their own abilities.
The first one to fill the board is the winner.

item.description:
From the publisher:
Robert's a great businessman, familiar characters take part in a duck Scrooge, organized by the thrill of competition, a businessman, to win a job Scrooge's group - the winner is the one who deserves the first million.
This game is monopoly/go for broke/payday/cashflow like game! The game goes around the board where players need to make decisions and some weird things, like to make a sound of money or what is the most expensive thing you know. Everytime when you get it right or other player think that you got it, then yu get the amount of money written on the card or on the spcae you are standing on!
Win, by getting a million!

In travel edition instead of the game board you have a small notebook for writing up the scores. Cards have modified accordingly. Travel version can be played up to 4 players.

Somewhere in Europe, near a big sea, there is a small village called Leiuatajateküla (Inventors Village), where it is thought as honor to be able to build and invent your own stuff. Every year they have a competition for inventions.
Who is the best inventor in the city? Maybe someone who can build a plane from paper and a string or a tractor from a old trumpet. Join in to take part in the best ever competition that ever was. This is a fast and tricky board game for 2 to 5 little inventors and fans of Lotte (Estonian animation), in where you have a lot of fun and no one will get hurt. Game fits for smaller and larger players, for academic and for school kids. Who wouldn't want to adventure with rabbit Adalbert and cat Bruno?
Be the first to finish your invention and score most with it to win the game.

In Monster Factory, the players take turns drawing and placing tiles, either adding to their own monsters or to those of their opponents. The goal is to make monsters that are big, but not so big that they go unfinished.

Nina Paley did the original art, with Marco Morte coloring it.

item.description: This is a childrens variant of Pachisi. Each player has just three pawns (characters from the movie Lion King). The track fields have five different colours. So does the die. If you roll RED you can move to the next red field. If you roll the blank side you can choose a colour.

name.value: Wir machen mit Spiel * Spannung * Umweltschutz

item.description:
Objective: keep on moving - do not meet (feed) a devil (4 of 
 them)
 find the correct answers for question cards
 cooperative game
moving by turn - drawing cards
story:
Family Grünkern (= 'unripe spelt grains') moves all over the board. If you flip a card find the correct answer - otherwise you will feed the 'devil marker' 
Questions like 'may you catch butterflies?' or
'may you drop a magazine onto a compost heap?'
content:
1 board
4 coloured meeples 
2 dice
1 enviromental little devil
4 polluters
143 cards
1 schedule/scheme
1 rules

With this game, children learn about geography, particularly topography. On the game board an illustrated map of the world is depicted. The continents are each in a different color, so they can be distinguished easily. The countries are easy to find by numbers and colors. At the edge of the board flags are shown.

The game contains 110 illustrated cards with questions (and answers) such as: Where do polar bears live? Where is the Eiffel Tower located? Background information, continents, countries and people pass by. Players have to respond the correct country, continent or ocean and have to designate them on the world map. By doing this correctly chips can be earned. The first player who has collected 8 chips wins the game.

The rules also describe a second way of playing. Here 24 random cards are put face up in the middle of the game board. The players take turns throwing a die and moving their pawn in accordance on the flags around the game board. They have to collect cards by selecting cards from the middle which are related to the country their pawn landed on. If no such a card is available, the player just has bad luck. Once a player reaches the last field, the player with the most cards wins.

WELTRAUMFAHRT is a roll-and-move dice game which was published around 1960.
What makes it special is the highly attractive artwork and the beautiful playing pieces shaped as small astronauts, which glow in the dark...

The Trouble with Rose is a co-operative story telling game with role playing and hand management. Players can collaboratively build a world, use an existing setting, or select one from a number of play sets.

Components: A standard deck of playing cards and a set of double six dominoes are required for play. Note taking materials for player created worlds and characters is suggested if a play set is not used.

Game Play: Each player is dealt a hidden agenda and either creates a character on the fly or uses one from the selected play set. Players then pull four to five dominoes (depending on the number playing.) The game begins with playing one of the dominoes from your hand and creating a scene based on the pips and their matching values for that character. After the scene, the remaining people at the table can embellish the scene and vote to determine if the player earned the points on the domino and can add it to their score. Play continues around the table until all the dominoes in hand are used. At that time, the hidden agendas are revealed and any bonus points are awarded. High score wins and gets to describe the fate of the players and any NPCs that were created.

Theme: TTwR started out as a Game Chef 2011 entry and was expanded and polished after the contest. The theme for GC'11 was Shakespeare and TTwR is designed to create character driven stories that tend to take tragic and comedic turns. Game play is wide open, but the rules provide the structure for story telling among strangers and play testing/con games have shown that the system delivers on the fun.

Objective: collect as many winning chips as possible

close to the rules of the popular TV-show you try to mislead your opponents placing your meeple as short as possible before the jingle is sounding onto 'true area'
the magic pen shows the correct answer (out of 3) and you should get a chip if you were right
 content:
- board
- magic pen
- 198 x 2 question & answer cards 
- 90 chips
- 9 meeples
- rules
battery is needed (for magic pen working)
depending on edition no. of cards may vary

The game board depicts a rug with three connected, diamond-shaped areas of 3 x 3 fields each. The goal is to get as many of one's own playing pieces to the far end of the board.
Each player has five coins. In each turn, a player can move a coin one field forward. When a coin can reach one of the opponent's coins, it climbs on top of that. This is called a Biri, it can move two fields, but not eliminate further coins. It can be caught by a single coin of the opponent. The resulting "Biribi" can move three fields and can't be eliminated. 
When a Biri or Biribi reaches the far end of the board, opponent's coins are discarded, one's own coins are scored. Whoever managed to get most coins across is the winner.

In Zombies ate my Brains (ZAMB) you are a newly created Zombie just trying to get some fresh human brains to keep you in peek undead form. Those pesky living ones however seem to want you dead, for real this time. Can you eat their brains before they destroy your rotting body? Find out if you have the right stuff come the Zombie Apocalypse.

ZAMB is a solo card game in which you have 2 decks, one is your play deck and the other is the Humans. You also have a set of cards to represent you the Zombie- which as you take damage changes your ability to draw cards and also effects your defence and offensive capabilities. Gameplay involves managing whatever the humans throw at you and using your hand/deck you try to defeat the game as more and more threats come into play. Picking the wrong option is deadly to the undead.

The Zombies over run the world and win if there are no more human cards left to play and yet your undead minion is still in (at least) one piece.

The game is a fast playing light card game which can also be played as a 2 player format with one player taking control of the Humans. In solo play the game rarely goes over 10 minutes play time.

name.value: Moth Eating Catz Destroyed my Broadband

item.description:
In Moth Eating Catz Destroyed My Broadband you are desperately trying to gain as much buzz as possible so people notice your spamchat and gain the win for the net, if only for your 15 seconds of fame.

Using advanced router technology you generate buzz but have to use moths and catz to deploy your assets to take down your fellow chatters. In this fast and fun game you will lolz, cry and win.

Remember its not the playing but the crushing your enemies that counts

This game is a random, light and chaotic game which contains- Moths, lolz Cats and random events as well as heavy dose of bad humour. The point of the game is to protect your router whilst generating buzz which in turn grants you Victory points. However you are limited in the actions you can take and will have to fight off the other players.

The game was inspired by random comments on the BGG chat feed for Essen 2011. It therefore is meant to evoke the random, bizarre and downright silly things that occur in chat feeds to live events when to many geeks gather together.

For untold centuries a war has been waged in the shadows cast by the moon. Two great powers of the underworld clash in repetitive fury, fighting for ultimate supremacy. The hedonistic Vampires believe it to be their birthright to own the night. The untamed Werewolves believe that none other than themselves should master the Earth. Whose claim is true? When twilight descends, which species will set the ancient records in stone and prove their powers of domination? Time to settle old scores. It’s time to Bare Your Fangs!

Bare Your Fangs is a two-player dice fighting game devoted to resolving once and for all which species will reign supreme: Vampire or Werewolf. Players choose their faction dice and roll to attack! The fully customized die icons determine successful hits, blocks, and of course, one’s ability to hunt for humans and thereby heal wounds incurred in these savage battles. But there is always risk. Some humans won’t go down without a fight! And one particular human seeks only the total annihilation of all creatures of the night. The Werewolf’s physical power is unmatched but the Vampire’s ability to heal is legendary. Only one will rule when dawn breaks, but will the victor crush his opponent into oblivion and take his rightful place as Leader Eternal, or will the fang fray destroy them both!

link.value: Bare Your Fangs: The Hunt is On

item.description:
The Hatter’s Table is board game about discovering the hidden and wonderfully strange rules that govern an apparently irrational situation. Set around the Mad Hatter’s table, players must dash around the Wonderland tea party while trying to figure out what secret rules govern the other players' movement. The Mad Hatter character serves as both an audio guide and aid to chaos.

How do you play?

Each player has a secret rule. When play begins, the Mad Hatter shouts out instructions about where to move around the table: "Go sit at a tea cup," "Take a seat next to the March Hare," "Move one place counter-clockwise." Players move their tokens accordingly, unless they find themselves in a situation where they must follow their secret rule instead.

Your goal is to guess what secret rules the other players are following. If you can do so successfully, you are rewarded with buttons, and the first player to get fifteen buttons wins the game!

At first, the game might seem like madness, but once you get the hang of it you'll learn to use some strategy. Watch the other players carefully and take note whenever they disobey the Hatter's direction - that's when you know they must be following their rule. Each place around the table has two different states, and every state has two positions around the table. When the Hatter tells you to sit next to the March Hare, a clever player will pick the spot next to the Hare that will best hide their secret rule.

Spears action game.

THe board has 8 sections, with a goal at the appropriate at every alternate side. If two play, opposite sections are played. If four play, then all goal-sections are used.

Each player has a 'puffer', a miniature bellows that, when pressed, ejects a stream of air. The object is to 'blow' the ball around the board, trying to get it into an opponent's goal.

The first to score 6 goals is the winner.

Objective: collect as many bonus points as possible

- roll & move game with action cards; moving by turn -
Each player tries to roll & move, picking up cards, helping enviroment and moving his/her stone along the scoring board/row
for more involved detectives (age 10..) a 'tracing set' can be added

Content:
1 board
5 wooden meeples (= 'Öko-detectives') 
5 wooden stones (scoring)
1 special 6-sided wooden die
30 wooden chips
26 event cards
12 cards for environmental sins
8 action slides
5 tracing-set-cards
1 rules

Miniature rules for tactical scale.
Science fiction infantry battles.

Space Man-2-Man was designed to reproduce large scale, tactical level Science Fiction miniature battles. The scale of the game is 1" equal 6 feet and each 'turn' for a combat group taking from 30 seconds to a few minutes. The game is designed with 25mm figures, but should be easy to covert the charts, movement rates and playing surface size to suit another scale if necessary.

"In Search of Eldorado" (In search of Eldorado) is a strategy game involving 2 teams (expeditionaries and indigenous) that can be composed of 1, 2 or 3 players each

The expeditionaries mission is a sea voyage aboard their galleons, from its port to the land of the Indians.

There are 3 pyramids spread over the territory of these.

Below one of the 3 pyramids is Eldorado. It'll be known by the brand that bears on the base. The only ones who know which of the pyramids is marked are the Indians.

The aim of the expedition will be to find and seize the pyramid that contains Eldorado and take it to the port where the expedition departed.

The Indians will be guarding the 3 pyramids, thus hindering the expeditionaries discovering which of them is Eldorado.

His other mission will be hunt down and eliminating the expeditionaries as soon as they land.

If any of the expeditionaries manages to find and grab the pyramid of Eldorado, the Indians will use all means at its disposal by land and sea to recover and return the pyramid of Eldorado to their place of origin.

The members of each team will decide among them wich piece they move each turn.

Severed Union 1861-1865 is a historical miniature war-game, which is the first release from Gordon & Hague War-games. The game uses 10mm pre-painted war-game miniatures to allow players to relive the greatest battles of the American Civil War. This game is a turn based in which each player will take turns moving, firing and charging. There are multiple ways to win according to what style of game you are playing. There are "take and hold" battles where you must capture key objectives around the battlefield in a specified amount of turns or simply play a "total destruction" game where you must destroy the enemy and run them from the tabletop!

The miniatures are 10mm in scale and pre-painted and are ready for battle right out of the box. The Severed Union Rulebook is free to download from our the Gordon & Hague website. There is an advanced 40 page rulebook for veteran war-gamers and there is also a 4 page quick-start rulebook for newcomers and children.

The game mechanics are based mainly around dice rolling and measuring. Maneuvering your units is also very important as you receive bonuses for being on high-ground and in or behind protective cover such as fences, buildings and forests.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Did you know that magical wizards are battling to the death ... and beyond ... right now!? "Why battle?" you might ask. "What have I got to prove, magic man?" Only who's the most awesomely powerful battle wizard in the entire realm, that's what! As a Battle Wizard, you'll put together up to three spell components to craft millions (okay, not really) of spell combos. Your spells might kick ass, or they could totally blow – it's up to you to master the magic. You will unleash massive damage on the faces of your wizard rivals in a no-holds-barred, all-out burn-down to be the last Battle Wizard standing. And it doesn't stop there! Powerful magic items bring on a whole new level of bloody carnage as you and your mighty wizard opponents tear each other limb from limb in an orgy of killing! Do you have what it takes to use epic spells in a war at Mt. Skullzfyre? Will YOU be the Ultimate Battle Wizard!?!

Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Duel at Mt. Skullzfyre is a humorous card game depicting a vicious, over-the-top battle between a variety of comically illustrated wizards. The game focuses primarily on creating three-part spell combos to blast your foes into the afterlife. The unique Dead Wizard cards allow players to stay in the game even after their wizards have been defeated.

item.description:
The war is over. Humanity has regained control. The zombies have been rounded up and contained. Time for people to get on with their lives. But there's no TV; no internet; society needs time to rebuild. What will the masses do for entertainment?

Zombie Roller Derby. In this game, you take the role of a roller derby team manager. Your team consists of "trained" zombies; your goal is to win the race, and maybe kill a few zombies along the way.

Race your zombies along the derby track. Play cards to urge them forward or to fight other zombies. Avoid the ire of the crowd, or stir them up on purpose. Play to win; to kill zombies; or to incite a riot. Just don't let the zombies get out of their cages...

item.description:
The new Goblin chiefs are ready to sound the charge and assault the castle! This time, the fortress is defended by a moat full of muddy water, but our fearless heroes did not come unprepared! Among the Goblin warriors are lifeguards, rafts, divers, fishermen, and even a pedal-boat – and they will all be needed to face the hazards (as well as the monsters!) hidden under the waters defending the castle! There are plenty of heroes of every kind, but this does not assure victory, especially when a fray erupts among the Goblins in the middle of the battlefield! But at the very end, there will be just one cry: Goooooobliiiiiiins!!!

Coming from the unleashed minds of 4G, Goblins: Epic Death, a fast-paced "card 'n' luck" game, is a new chapter in the saga of our green-skinned little friends. Victory is at hand, and the castle is ready for capture: Both are just an "epic death" away from you! So toss your Goblins, cross your fingers, and pray they all die. That way, victory will be yours!

item.description:
HOCKEY BLAST is an "old-school" card-chart-and-dice simulation of pro hockey. Primarily designed as a solitaire game for sports board game hobbyists, it can also be played head-to-head, with each player making decisions for his team. It was introduced by PLAAY Games in April of 2010.

The game differs significantly from similarly-themed hockey games in a number of ways.

First, it re-creates hockey action totally differently than existing games like APBA and Strat-O-Matic. Rather than re-creating a hockey game pass-by-pass and shot-by-shot, HOCKEY BLAST re-creates the action minute-by-minute. The game charts crystallize each minute's action, and a unique "lull" mechanism allows the gamer to fast-forward past uneventful minutes. The result is a hockey game that plays quickly, yet captures all the nuances and excitement of real hockey.

Second, HOCKEY BLAST realistically incorporates momentum and fights into the game play. In HOCKEY BLAST, a team plays better when it has momentum. It can gain momentum in a number of ways--by landing a big hit, scoring a goal, making a spectacular save, or having one of its players win a fight. In other hockey games, fights can occur, but have no real effect on the game other than to send participants to the penalty box. In HOCKEY BLAST, the classic hockey "enforcer" persona has a real role, just as in real hockey.

Another way HOCKEY BLAST is different is that it provides fans with instructions on how to rate their own players and teams. The company encourages this, and even posts user-created card sets for free download on its website, www.plaay.com.

The game comes in a two-piece labeled box with a game book that contains all the necessary charts, a hockey rink game board, a set of strategy cards, dice, markers for momentum and penalties, an instructions booklet, scoresheets, and two sample teams. Full player card sets based on historical pro hockey seasons are available, along with a fictional player card series that is updated annually.

item.description:
This game is a roll-and-move game with wonderful graphics on the gameboard (world map) and especially interesting for collectors on the box cover: It shows a large Zeppelin waiting to be tossed into its hangar.
It's supposed to be the so called "Reparations - Zeppelin" LZ 126, which obviously inspired the artist to draw this box cover

GB Racers: The Ultimate Car Racing Board Game (Second Edition)

Strap in for the ride of your life in this fast-paced Formula 1 simulation board game.

Appleton Games proudly presents GB Racers (Golden Ball Racers), a fast-paced game inspired by F1 Racing. This exciting new F1 Racing board game infusing the ‘Appleton Way’ a sporting chance of success for everyone, every time.

You can play as 1 player using all 6 teams of 12 cars, or up to 6 players combined using the historical GB Racer cards. Also experience the unique GB (Golden Ball) 20 sided dice and other special features.

GB Racers board game is for 1 – 6 players, where you have 2 racing cars each and must get 77 points or more to win the GB Championship. This you do by picking up points for both cars during several GB Grand Prix races. Each race takes 12 – 20 minutes to complete & there is an average of 4 – 5 races per championship.
The overall time averages just over 1 hour.

name.value: Shadows Upon Lassadar: Sorrow of Salilth

item.description:
Sorrow of Salilth is a microgame for one or two players lasting about 20 minutes. When playing a 2 player game, one player assumes the role of the Council of Wardens, trying to defend the city of Salilth from the servants of the Grayking and close four barrier gates within the city. If the four gates are closed or all of the Servant units are defeated, Salilth is saved and the Warden Player wins.

The other player controls the forces of the Grayking trying to overwhelm Salilth and reach the Citadel of the Wardens where they attempt to place 10 Siege Corruption tokens within the Citadel, If they are successful, or can defeat all of the Warden Units, Salilth is lost and the Grayking Player wins.

When playing the solitaire variant, the player assumes the Council of Wardens role.

Needed: one 2-page hex map, 1 rule sheet, 1 unit counter sheet and 1 sheet of nomograph tables.

Setup: The Warden Player places all of their units inside the Citadel, stacked by type.
The player should also take the 4 Barrier Gate tokens, placing them within reach. They then place the marker on the Sparkblades icon on the Spell Rondel.

The Grayking Player divides their units into 6 stacks each with 6 unit counters. These stacks may be configured as desired by the player. They then place one stack on each of the 6 numbered zones outside the city. The player should also take the 10 Siege Corruption Tokens, placing them within reach.

Play: Each round of the game has 4 phases: Movement, Combat, Damage, Siege. Then a new round begins. The Grayking Player always goes first each phase, followed by the Warden Player.

Win: If all 4 gates are closed or all of Servant units are defeated, Salilth is saved and the Warden Player wins. If 10 Siege Corruption tokens are placed in the Citadel or all Warden Units are defeated, the Grayking Player wins.

Solitaire Variant: At game start, randomly sort the Grayking units into the 6 stacks of 6 units each, and place each stack randomly on each of the 6 numbered starting zones. During the Movement Phase, the player will move the Grayking units based on the rules as outlined above. Movement will always occur towards the Citadel and units will always form a larger group if there is a path choice. When splitting 4 or more units, always move units in order of the largest Spirit Strength first. During the Siege Phase, one Siege Corruption Token is added each round as long as any Servant unit occupies the Citadel.

This game uses nomographs instead of look-up tables and was designed to use a minimum number of components.

Sorrow of Salilth is a prequel to the Print and Play game - Shadows Upon Lassadar. A further game - Revenge of the Raven Consort - will complete the game trilogy.

Winner of the 2011 BGG Microgame contest

A game published in junction with the student carnival "Lundakarnevalen 2010". The game is a word-game, where players try to descibe words without mentioning specifics (very similar to Alias).

Players take turn to try to describe the words on the card, each one with a specific theme, without mentioning the specific word or part of the word. The other players, teammates or opponents depending on the variant, try to guess as many as possible in a set period of time; and players score accordingly. First one to a set target of points is the winner.

What sets the game apart from Alias is the distinct tongue-in-cheek "lundahumor", i.e. humour from the student city of Lund. The themes and words on the different cards are often odd, screwball or intergroup.

In addition to the original rules, several variants is included in the base-game.

"They are hungry!
The only way to safety is to climb up. . . or is it?"

Dexterity based game in which your zombies are trying to reach the human of the other player. Be careful, or your zombies will tumble down and they'll have to make their way up again.

Game is simple: On the player's turn he or she gets a randomised zombie which must be placed against the opponent's wall. The goal is to get the pile high enough to touch the human. Players place one zombie at the time and try to catch the opponent's human before their own human is zombie food.

Objective: Collect as many cheese cake pieces as possible by moving around the board
 - moving/acting by turn -
each player has to collect cheese cake pieces for Diddle. You can achieve this if you have to draw a question card => give the right answer or
if you draw an action card => perform required action properly
If all players are back in Diddls' cave the one who gained most of the pieces wins

Rules for game: First, place the animals (Elephant, Alligator, Camel, Zebra, Lion and Goat) on the board using set up rules , then 1st player rolls dice and then can do any of 3 things.

1) Place hunter on the board and then move him the total of both dice

or

2) place hunter on board move him total of 1 die then place second hunter on board and move him total of 2nd die

or

3) start hunter move him total of 1 die then place peg on board horizontally or vertically the distance away from hunter equal to the 2nd die.

Object of the game is to continue to make those die rolls and try and to surround the animals. Game ends when all animals have been caught. Scoring is as follows: Elephant, Alligator and Camel= 4 points. Zebra and Lion = 3 points and Goat = 2 points.

User Summary

Slapjack is a simple children's boardgame that appears to be related to, but distinct from, the Slap Jack card game...

At the beginning of the game all 44 cards are dealt face down to the players. (These are kept face down during the course of the game.) Players use a spinner to move cardboard pawns around a board. Each space has an instruction for the player to follow. Some spaces ask players to perform physical actions (which have no real effect on game play). Some spaces ask players to give or take cards from other players. This is significant because the object of the game is to collect all the cards. If you run out of cards you are eliminated.

There are a few strategically placed Slapjack spaces on the board. If someone lands on one of these spots, then each player takes a card at random (again all cards are kept face down at all times) and puts it in the center of the board. If someone puts down a Slapjack card, then the first player that slaps the card wins the hand.

There is a variant game listed in the rules where players use just the game cards and play a single card down one at a time. If a Slapjack card is played, then the first player to slap the card wins the hand. The last player with any cards wins. (This is essentially the Slap Jack card game, albeit with a smaller than standard deck.)

Straddle is a skill-action party game played on a giant planisphere (5 ft x 6 ft plastic playing mat) and combines a fun mix of practical and observational astronomy. Playing like Hasbro’s classic Twister game, the object is to touch a star or constellation using only your feet or hands and be the last player not to touch any other body part to the mat.

Each player stands at a corner of the mat in socks or bare feet. The umpire spins the spinner and calls out the body part and the star or constellation, for example, left hand Orion. The first player puts his or her left hand on the constellation Orion. Using the supplied star charts, the umpire can help a player determine what stars are in the constellation. Play continues to the next player.

If a player touches the mat with any body part except a hand or a foot, that player is eliminated. Be the last player not to touch any other body part to the Straddle mat to win the game.

An abstract game on a 5x6 grid of African origin. It is similar to Dara with a few exeptions.

Each player has 12 pieces (stones, bids, etc.) of his colour. During initial set-up players take turns to place their pieces on empty squares of the board, two pieces (one piece in Dara) at a time. They must avoid 'three in a row' orthogonally during this phase.

In the second phase players move their pieces to adjacent squares trying to form 'three in a row' (diagonals don't count). After making 'three in a row' a player removes an enemy piece which is adjacent to either side of this row (that's another difference to Dara). A player loses the game when only 2 pieces of his colour remain on the board.

After the retirement of captain "White Beard", the crew of a pirate ship decides do rotate positions. Each round, a new player becomes captain and pick roles for everybody else. In order, the pirates take a treasure (pearls, diamonds, rubys, emeralds or rum barrels) from a hand of cards. Precious stones translate into victory points and rum barrels confer "special powers" to the players who hold them. But not all treasures will be banked safely - Spanish, French and English pirate-hunters will force the crew to discard some cards along the game.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
